content: this legal document is a summary of the progress of a legal case involving the dissolution of a matrimonial property regime and the division of immovable property located in belgium the case initially had a decision in france ordering the liquidation and division of the couples property but the belgian court asserts jurisdiction and states that the french courts authority ends at the national border the belgian court emphasizes the need for the parties to resolve the matter in the belgian court and appoint a notary for the property division the court dismisses a counterclaim and rejects a claim for damages due to a lack of evidence ultimately the judge orders the liquidation and partition of the immovable property in belgium and appoints a liquidating notary for the process the text also discusses a regulation law passed in 2011 that reformed the procedure for liquidating assets in cases involving parties from different countries it highlights the complexities of dividing property in international divorce cases and the need for legal intervention

civil_codes_used: The law of 13 August 2011 reforming the judicial liquidation and partition procedure
The Franco-Belgian Convention of 8 July 1899 on Jurisdiction, Authority, and Enforcement of Judicial Decisions, Judicial Awards, and Authentic Instruments
